revision.text:
{{nihongo|'''Nagao Kita'''|喜多 長雄|Kita Nagao|}} was a [[Japan]]ese Consul <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bartcop.com/arc4109.htm |title=Project 60 - "The First Fight Against Fascism" - Archives September, 1941 |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref> stationed in [[Hawaii]]. He received instructions on March 22, 1941 to gather information about the schedule of the [[United States|American]] fleet at [[Pearl Harbor]], by bribery, if necessary.<ref name=Gilbert2004>{{cite book|author=Martin Gilbert|title=The Second World War: A Complete History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tFN7BR1HSIsC&pg=PA163|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=June 2004|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-8050-7623-3}}</ref>{{rp|page=163}} These instructions were intercepted by U.S. intelligence but did not raise alarms.
He received further instructions on September 24, 1941 to report the locations of American aircraft in bases in Hawaii. These instructions were also intercepted but did not raise alarms.<ref name=Gilbert2004/>{{rp|page=2}} The intercepted message was sent to [[Washington, DC]] by sea, not by air, and when eventually decoded, was not thought by American intelligence to be useful.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.safran-arts.com/42day/history/h4sep/h4sep24.html |title=Events, deaths, births, of Sep 24 |author= |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
